runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this realistic fiction story is about a girl reusing something broken to make something new.
Have students look at the illustrations to identify the main characters.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means something that has been found.
of a new insect is exciting to scientists.
Name someone from history who made an important
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find two words that describe Keesha at the beginning of the story. (bored, unhappy)
What discovery does Keesha make in the garage? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How does Keesha reuse the broken mold? Describe the process.
Have you ever reused an old or broken object in a new way? What did you do?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text is a comic about prefixes and how to use them. The photos help readers understand the ideas in captions and speech bubbles.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
to me. I think Ive been here before.
sights and sounds in your neighborhood?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find Renatas first example of a word with a prefix. (unhappy)
What does unruly mean? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Which base words in the text are familiar to you? Which are new to you?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words that begin with
. Have them draw a box around words that begin with
Then have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss phrasing, or how to chunk longer sentences into meaningful parts.
For example, as you read sentence 1, pause briefly after
Point out that each group of words builds on the information presented in the previous group.
Read the title. Discuss the different meanings of the word
Explain that this is a comic. Remind students that they should pay attention to the illustrations as well as the words in the speech bubbles.
For the first reading, have students read the boy in blues speech bubbles while you read the boy in greens speech bubbles.
Then pair students to reread the text, with each partner reading for one character. Partners can switch roles during the rereadings.
Prompt students to find all of the words with prefixes
Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
These supports include the Read/Build/Write routine.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read an informational text about different kinds of rocks. Have students identify the heading of each section.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
are groups of similar items within a larger group.
of books can you find at the library?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find a word in the Sedimentary Rocks section that begins with the prefix
How do igneous rocks form? Find the sentences that answer this question.
What are the three categories of rocks? How are they alike and different?
Which facts from the text did you already know? Which facts are new to you?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with prefixes
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 1 (exclamation point), 2 (question mark), and 4 (period).
Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with emotion).
Then have students read the sentences consecutively.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text includes a chart with labels and images.
Have students identify the name of the rock in the second row of the chart.
Guide students through a reading of the text, including the chart.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the chart.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a story about a boy planning his winter birthday party.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
with his performance in the race.
When do you feel the most
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that tells what Tyler wants Mom to do with the invitation. (recheck)
What does Tyler want to do at his birthday party? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why does Tyler smile at the end of the story? Explain.
Would you feel satisfied with cold weather on your birthday? Why or why not?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat.
Explain that this text is a journal entry about water and how it can change.
Have students look closely at the diagram about the water cycle.
using the Define/Example/Ask routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
Pedro uses a pen and a notepad to
notes by hand or on a computer?
Have students whisperread the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the adjective the writer uses to describe water. (unusual)
What riddle does the writer record? Find the sentence that answers the question.
How does the diagram support the main text of the journal entry? Explain.
What questions about water do you still have? How can you find the answers?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
